bibl.title: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Joseph A. LePrince, January 11, 1922

div1.p: Carter writes to LePrince concerning three papers on water impoundment he gave to the U.S. Army Surgeon General.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Rose Carter to Joseph A. LePrince, January 11, 1922
div1.opener:
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
January 11, 1922
/LC
Senior Sanitary Engineer,
U. S. Public Health Service,
Room 17, Court House Building,
Memphis, Tenn.
Dear LePrince:
div1.p:
I gave 3 papers to the Office of the Surgeon General of the
Army:--

1) A copy of the Recommendation of the Federal Water Power Commission--
sent me by Dr. Fricks last fall:

2) The Memorandum given General Beach, at his request, the sum-
mer of 1921:

3) A copy of the recently received Regulations of the Alabama
State Board of Health.

The first and last you have. The 2nd. I am herewith enclosing.
Please return it to me, as it is the last of my copies, being, indeed,
made by Woodfall when I submitted my only remaining copy to him. in 1921

These were given, at Dr. Stimson's instance, so that they--the
Surgeon General's Office, U. S. A.: the U. S. Engineers or anybody
else--might know what were the requisites for a pond area before
filling. I told Colonel Siler's representative--Major Dunham--that
Dr. Welch had expressed himself as satisfied with the requirements
of the first paper named: that I knew they had not been accepted by
the Federal Power Commission (ofonly the U. S. Engineers) as of universal ap-
plicability, but that they were being enforced in certain projects
after individual decisions that they were necessary for such projects--
This, I understand, is the case for the Pool of Lock No. 8, Coosa.
Coosa.

The other two papers were submitted, as being more in detail of
what was implicitly required in the first.

Very obviously, the estimate you are going to make is to deter-
mine the cost of the preparation required for what is necessary for this individual project.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, H. R. Carter
Assistant Surgeon General,
On Waiting Orders. Enclosures.
